p.text: In this Division:
means commission referred to in section 86 of the Probate and Administration Act 1898.
, in respect of an estate the subject of proceedings for the passing of accounts, means the proceedings in which:
probate or administration has been granted, or
a foreign grant has been resealed,
in respect of the estate.

defterm.emph: proceedings for the passing of accounts

p.text: means proceedings for an order passing accounts under section 85 of the Probate and Administration Act 1898.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [SCR Pt 78 r 76] r 76 Commencement of proceedings

p.text: Proceedings for the passing of accounts for an estate must be commenced by notice of motion in the parent proceedings.
The notice may, but need not, request the Court to allow the applicant to be paid commission from the assets of the estate.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [SCR Pt 78 r 77] r 77 Further requirements where applicant seeks commission

leg:heading.title: Further requirements where applicant seeks commission

p.text: If the applicant seeks commission he or she must file with the notice of motion commencing the proceedings:
an affidavit in support of the application, and
where the accounts were not filed within the time fixed by the rules or any order of the Court, an affidavit explaining the delay.
Legislation cited in [SCR Pt 78.77.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Wills, Probate and Administration Act 1898 ss 86, 86A.

Under the general law (unless the testator’s will made specific provision) trustees, executors or administrators were not entitled to payment for carrying out the functions of their office: In the Will of Sheldon [1972] 1 NSWLR 196 ; In the Will of Sheppard [1972] 2 NSWLR 714 . That position is altered by the court’s statutory discretions to allow a “just and reasonable” commission, and to disallow excessive commission: Probate and Administration Act 1898 ss 86 & 86A . The power to allow commission includes compensation for professional work undertaken by the executor in connection with the estate: Re Craig (1952) 52 SR (NSW) 265; 69 WN (NSW) 205 .

The court’s power to allow commission is ordinarily contingent on the executor or administrator filing their estate accounts, and having them passed by the court. If executors do not file their accounts the court will only grant commission in exceptional circumstances: In the Will of Bye (1933) 50 WN (NSW) 226; but see In the Estate of Watkins (1916) 16 SR (NSW) 135; 33 WN (NSW) 23 . The entitlement of a trustee or executor to commission depends on the propriety and utility of their conduct. Trustees or executors will not be entitled to commission, at least not without appropriate discount, where they have been guilty of wilful default or neglect in the administration of the estate: In the Will of Sherringham (1901) 1 SR (NSW) B&P 48; 18 WN (NSW) 121; In the Will of Greer (1911) 11 SR (NSW) 21; 28 WN (NSW) 17a . In its equitable jurisdiction, although not pursuant to the powers contained in s 86, the court may authorise trustees to deduct their commission from moneys which they receive in the future: In the Will of Gaukrodger (1915) 15 SR (NSW) 192; 32 WN (NSW) 40 .

level.toc-caption: [SCR Pt 78.77.10] Testamentary gifts to executors — commission and charges

p.text: Legislation cited in [SCR Pt 78.77.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Wills, Probate and Administration Act 1898 s 86.

heading.title: Testamentary gifts to executors — commission and charges

p.text: Where the will provides a legacy to the executors there is a presumption that it was intended to be full and sufficient compensation for their work as executors: In the Will of Steele (1915) 15 SR (NSW) 247; 32 WN (NSW) 66 ; In the Will of Oddie [1976] 1 NSWLR 371 . This presumption is not rebutted merely by proof of the close friendship between testators and executors.

The authorities suggest that there is a distinction between a legacy that is given to an executor by virtue of their office, and a legacy that is expressed to be a substitute for any right to commission.

Where the legacy has been granted to executors “by virtue of their office”, they may reject the legacy and apply for an allowance of “just and reasonable” commission: In the Will of Bomlin (1919) 19 SR (NSW) 277; 36 WN (NSW) 104b ; In the Will of Wheelihan (1912) 29 WN (NSW) 98 ; Public Trustee v Molloy (1933) 33 SR (NSW) 125; 50 WN (NSW) 42 . And if an executor is permitted by the will to charge for any professional services they provide, the executors may either make such charges and have the amounts moderated in the passing of their accounts, or they may make no charges and apply for commission in the usual way. If an executor is also permitted by the will to charge for non-professional services they may also elect whether to charge or to apply for commission: In the Will of Marsden (1926) 43 WN (NSW) 170 ; In the Will of Phair (1933) 50 WN (NSW) 207. In these instances, therefore, executors must elect whether to take the legacy in the will or to renounce it and apply for commission under s 86 of the Probate and Administration Act 1898: In the Will of Levy (1885) 1 WN (NSW) 167; In the Will of Pauton (1909) 26 WN (NSW) 51 .

Where the legacy has been granted as a substitute for commission, executors take office on the basis that they have accepted the condition, and the sufficiency of the legacy. In that case they cannot be allowed additional commission: Re Burkedin (1901) 1 SR (NSW) B&P 1; 18 WN (NSW) 156; In the Will of Morrison (1933) 50 WN (NSW) 88 ; In the Will of Oddie [1976] 1 NSWLR 371 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [SCR Pt 78 r 78] r 78 Objection prior to proceedings

p.text: At any time prior to the commencement of proceedings for the passing of accounts for an estate in respect of which:
probate or administration has been granted, or
a foreign grant has been resealed,
any person (the objector) may, by filing a notice of his or her intention to do so, object to the passing of accounts or the allowance of commission, as the case may be.
The address for service shown in the notice is taken to be the objector’s address for service in any such proceedings.
On the commencement of any such proceedings, the registrar must serve a copy of the notice on the applicant.
As soon as practicable after being served with such a copy, the applicant in any such proceedings must serve a copy of the originating process on the objector.
The approved form for a notice of intended objection to estate accounts is UCPR Form 143.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [SCR Pt 78 r 79] r 79 Notice of proceedings

p.text: At least 14 days before the commencement of proceedings for the passing of accounts, the applicant must cause to be published a notice of:
the filing of the accounts, and
the order or orders claimed in the proceedings.
The notice must be published:
if, when he or she died, the deceased was resident in New South Wales, in a newspaper circulating in the district where the deceased resided, or
in any other case, in a Sydney daily newspaper.
The applicant must file an affidavit of compliance with this rule.
The Court may order the applicant to give notice of the proceedings to any person.
The approved form for a notice of filing of an executor or administrator’s accounts is UCPR Form 144.

At least 14 days before the commencement of proceedings for the passing of accounts for an estate in respect of which an administration bond has been executed under section 64 of the Probate and Administration Act 1898, the plaintiff must serve on each surety to the bond a copy of the notice referred to in rule 79(1).
The plaintiff must file an affidavit of compliance with subrule (1).

Instead of or in addition to complying with subrules (1) and (2) in respect of any surety, the plaintiff may file the consent of the surety to an order passing the accounts, with an affidavit verifying the consent endorsed on the document containing the consent.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [SCR Pt 78 r 81] r 81 Inspection and appearance

p.text: This rule applies if proceedings for the passing of accounts have been commenced but the hearing of the proceedings has not been completed.
Any person may inspect the accounts at any time after the commencement of the proceedings, without leave, unless the registrar otherwise directs.
Any person intending to object to the passing of the accounts may, at any time before completion of the hearing, enter an appearance in the proceedings.
Any person entering an appearance in the proceedings is to be joined as a defendant in the proceedings.
Unless the Court otherwise directs, accounts are to be vouched:
in the absence of the public, and
without the appearance before the Court of any person, and
without an appointment being obtained for the vouching.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [SCR Pt 78 r 83] r 83 Court may require further evidence, documents and notices

leg:heading.title: Court may require further evidence, documents and notices

p.text: In any proceedings for the passing of accounts, the Court:
may require further evidence to be furnished, further documents to be filed and further notices to be given, and
if satisfied that the accounts are correct, may make an order passing the accounts, and
if satisfied that any commission that is sought is appropriate, may make an order allowing commission.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [SCR Pt 78 r 84] r 84 Certificate as to passing of accounts

leg:heading.title: Certificate as to passing of accounts

p.text: If the Court makes an order passing accounts, the registrar is to issue the applicant with a certificate as to the balance of the accounts.
If the Court makes an order allowing commission, the certificate must also certify as to:
the amount of capital realised, and
the amount of income collected, and
the value of any assets transferred to beneficiaries, and
where a business was carried on, the gross receipts and net profit earned or loss incurred,
during the period to which the accounts relate.
Legislation cited in [SCR Pt 78.84.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Wills, Probate and Administration Act 1898 s 85(3), Section 87.

As a general rule commission will only be allowed as an incident of the passing of accounts. But, commission may not be the only reason to induce executors or administrators to wish to have their accounts passed by the court.

“In some cases an executor might be unhappy about the reception of his accounts by the beneficiaries and wish to have them approved. In other cases, he might be one of a number of trustees of a deceased estate and desire the handling of the estate moneys by the others to be approved, or he might wish to retire and to obtain a complete clearance for himself and his own estate. The court itself, on removal of a trustee and appointment of a new trustee may, in order to give the former trustee a clearance, order the accounts of the retiring trustee to be passed”: Vance, Executors' Commission at 45.

It is to serve these wider purposes and to give an additional incentive to comply with the primary obligations that s 85(3) of the Probate and Administration Act 1898 provides that the order of the court allowing the account shall be prima facie evidence of the correctness of the same and shall after the expiration of three years from the date of such order, operate as a limited form of release to the person filing the same. Section 87 of the Probate and Administration Act 1898 provides power to compel the passing of accounts and also the repayment of any amount disallowed to the estate.
For a discussion generally in relation to accounts including costs and disbursements which might properly be claimed by solicitors see Executors' Accounts (1993) 67 ALJ 309.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [SCR Pt 78 r 85] r 85 Time for filing etc accounts under section 85 of P&A Act

leg:heading.title: Time for filing etc accounts under section 85 of P&A Act

p.text: For the purposes of section 85(1) and (1AA) of the Probate and Administration Act 1898, the time within which accounts for an estate in respect of which:
probate or administration has been granted, or
a foreign grant has been resealed,
must be filed, verified and filed or verified, filed and passed, as the case requires, is 12 months after the relevant grant or resealing.

An executor or administrator may, in the proceedings for the grant of probate or administration or the resealing of a foreign grant, move for an order extending the period for compliance with section 85(1) or (1AA) of the Probate and Administration Act 1898, including an order extending the period until the further order of the Court, without the prior filing or service of notice of the motion.

These rules do not fix a time limit under section 85(1A), (1B) or (5) of the Probate and Administration Act 1898. Subject to any order made by the Court, no time limit will therefore apply under those subsections.

level.toc-caption: [SCR Pt 78.85.5] Time for filing estate accounts

p.text: Legislation cited in [SCR Pt 78.85.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Wills, Probate and Administration Act 1898 s 85(1), s 85(1A), (1AA).

This rule sets the general time limits for the filing of estate accounts, and provides for the court to grant an extension time for the filing of accounts: see Probate and Administration Act 1898 s 85(1) and (1AA) .

The overriding effect of s 85(1AA) of the Probate and Administration Act 1898 is that the manner and timing of the filing of estate accounts is subject to the court’s order. The court may impose a requirement to file accounts, but in the absence of such an order the automatic requirement to file accounts generally only applies to executors or administrators who are either creditors or guardians, or where a substantial part of the estate passes to a charity or benevolent institution.

The practical effect of these provisions is that there are instances where there is no requirement to file accounts — even though there is no specific provision for dispensing with the filing of the accounts. One instance where it is appropriate not to require the filing of estate accounts is where executors had merely transferred the estate assets to a trustee company who accepted them without requiring accounts to be passed: In the Will of Green (1901) 27 VLR 228; 8 ALR (CN) 1b . As to whether the poverty of the estate is a reason for making an order, see Re Evans [1902] QWN 81 and Re King (1899) 9 QLJ (NC) 55.

Where there is a requirement to file accounts the court may, in any event, extend the time for compliance: Probate and Administration Act 1898 s 85(1A) . The most common case where such an order will be made is where a grant has been made to all of the persons beneficially entitled to the estate and where there is evidence that debts, funeral and testamentary expenses have been paid — or are otherwise fully protected: see In the Goods of Rolland (1893) 14 LR (NSW) B & P 102; Re Thompson's Will (1896) 7 QLJ 89; 7 QLJ (NC) N47 ; Re Murray's Will (1898) 9 QLJ (NC) 30; Re Jordan [1943] QWN 27 ; Re Milineaux [1954] QWN 19 ; Re Brown [1955] QWN 49 ; Re Farmer [1955] QWN 14 ; Re Irving [1957] QWN 15 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [SCR Pt 78 r 86] r 86 Renunciation of commission under section 86 (3) of P&A Act

leg:heading.title: Renunciation of commission under section 86 (3) of P&A Act

p.text: If, in any proceedings for the passing of accounts, the applicant wishes to renounce his or her right to commission:
the applicant may do so, at any time before the hearing of the proceedings, by filing a renunciation of commission, and
if the applicant does so, the accounts must be allowed in accordance with the indemnity referred to in section 86(3) of the Probate and Administration Act 1898.

Under section 86(3) of the Probate and Administration Act 1898, an executor, administrator or trustee who renounces their right to commission for work carried out in relation to a deceased’s estate, and engages a legal practitioner to do that work (being non-professional work) on their behalf, is entitled to be indemnified by the estate, up to the amount of commission to which they would otherwise be entitled, for the legal practitioner’s charges and disbursements in connection with that work.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [SCR Pt 78 r 87] r 87 Reduction of excessive commission under section 86A of P&A Act

leg:heading.title: Reduction of excessive commission under section 86A of P&A Act

p.text: Proceedings for an order under section 86A of the Probate and Administration Act 1898 are to be commenced by notice of motion in the parent proceedings.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [SCR Pt 78 r 88] r 88 Notices and orders under section 87 of P&A Act

leg:heading.title: Notices and orders under section 87 of P&A Act

p.text: A notice or order under section 87 of the Probate and Administration Act 1898 may be served by sending it to the executor, administrator or trustee concerned at his or her address for service in relation to the parent proceedings.

If an order has been made under section 87 of the Probate and Administration Act 1898 requiring an executor, administrator or trustee to show cause, any application for an order extending the period referred to in section 87(1) of that Act must be made on the day appointed for showing cause.
Legislation cited in [SCR Pt 78.88.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Wills, Probate and Administration Act 1898 s 87.

Under the general law all trustees (including executors and administrators) have stringent obligations to keep and to render proper accounts and to give full information to beneficiaries when required: see Re Craig (1952) 52 SR (NSW) 265; 69 WN (NSW) 205 and R P Meagher and W M C Gummow, Jacob's Law of Trusts in Australia, 4th ed, Butterworths, Sydney, 1977, at [1712]–[1713]. This obligation is reinforced by s 87 of the Probate and Administration Act 1898. That section permits the Court to limit the time by which an executor, administrator or trustee must file estate accounts and it imposes a fine liability for non-compliance with the requirement to file the estate accounts.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [SCR Pt 78 r 89] r 89 Order to file etc accounts

p.text: Proceedings for an order that an executor, administrator or trustee of a deceased person’s estate do any of the following:
file an inventory,
verify and file an inventory,
file accounts,
verify and file accounts,
file and pass accounts,
verify, file and pass accounts,
pass accounts filed,
must be commenced by notice of motion in the parent proceedings.

level.toc-caption: [SCR Pt 78.89.5] Principles relating to the form of accounts

heading.title: Principles relating to the form of accounts

p.text: Because of the almost infinite variety of estates no form has been prescribed for accounts to be filed. In In the Will of White (1908) 8 SR (NSW) 582 at 585–6; 25 WN (NSW) 187 Street J said:

Accounts as brought in before the Registrar may often consist merely of an indiscriminate mass of receipts on the one side and disbursements on the other. I think that in every case separate accounts should be brought in of capital and income, showing the receipts and disbursements on account of each; and where the amounts include the accounts of a business carried on by executors, I think that there should be separate trading accounts, either in the form of a balance sheet and a profit and loss account, or in such other form as may be sufficient to show clearly and accurately the result of the year's operations.
See also Re Bowman [1955] SASR 98 and Executors' Accounts (1993) 67 ALJ 309.

level.toc-caption: [SCR Pt 78.89.10] The function of the court in passing accounts

p.text: Legislation cited in [SCR Pt 78.89.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Supreme Court Rules 1970 r 94(3).

heading.title: The function of the court in passing accounts

p.text: On the one hand the registrar may allow proper disbursements, even where they are not specifically provided for in the will: Chesterman v Mitchell (1923) 24 SR (NSW) 108; 41 WN (NSW) 11 ; Re Macarthur (1908) 24 WN (NSW) 211 (costs of the erection of a monument over the testator's grave). In addition, the cost of obtaining a surety may in some circumstances be allowed: In the Estate of Gracey (1917) 17 SR (NSW) 239; 34 WN (NSW) 101 .

On the other hand, the registrar may disallow disbursements that appear to have been made in breach of trust or are not properly chargeable against the estate: In the Will of Lucas-Tooth (No 1) (1931) 49 WN (NSW) 18 ; on appeal In the Will of Lucas-Tooth (No 2) (1932) 50 WN (NSW) 86 .

level.toc-caption: [SCR Pt 78.89.15] Power of registrar to modify accounts

heading.title: Power of registrar to modify accounts

p.text: In passing the accounts filed for the executors the Registrar may moderate bills for costs for which the executor seeks reimbursement out of the estate, notwithstanding that the bills have not yet been paid: Shave v Shave; Estate of Shave (2011) 5 ASTLR 320; [2011] NSWSC 1356; BC201108915 .
